learning_outcomes.description: Demonstrate a foundational level of artistry and technical fluency as a solo performer
Identify your progress at a foundational level towards being a professional musician.
Demonstrate a foundational level of artistry as an ensemble performer and your awareness of professional expectations surrounding ensemble performance in varied contexts at a foundational level

assessments.due_date:
Week 1 - Week 13

You are assessed on your participation and progression throughout the semester.
assessments.task_description:
Through the weekly lessons, students receive feedback from their teachers on their development towards becoming a professional musician.

At the end of semester, your allocated teacher will provide you with a final report summarising this feedback. If you have more than one allocated teacher, they will collaborate and provide you with a single final report.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.late_submission: You will receive a mark of 0 if this assessment is submitted late.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.due_date:
Week 1 - Week 13

You are assessed on your participation and progression throughout the semester.
assessments.task_description:
Students must demonstrate development appropriate to their year level as ensemble performers and are expected to attend the weekly class relevant to their studies

Students who participate in UQ School of Music ensemble and group music making classes, together with any associated performances, are assessed on their development, contribution and participation throughout the semester through an ensemble director report. Vocal students in Performance Studies 1-3 must also pass a diction test.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.late_submission: You will receive a mark of 0 if this assessment is submitted late.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.due_date:
Week 1 - Week 13

You are assessed on your participation and progression throughout the semester.
assessments.task_description:
Students are expected to attend the weekly workshop specific to their principal study. If you are not certain which workshop to attend, please speak to the course coordinator.

Students must demonstrate development throughout the semester appropriate to their year level by participation in workshop activities, and are assessed through a workshop director report.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.late_submission: You will receive a mark of 0 if this assessment is submitted late.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.due_date:
Composition Portfolios due Monday 5 PM, 17 November 2025.

Performance recitals will be scheduled in Exam Week One and Two. A schedule will be published to Blackboard no later than the end of Week 13.
assessments.task_description:
Students will prepare a recital or portfolio, dependent on their approved instrument.

Instrument and Vocal students will prepare a recital program of 20 minutes of appropriate repertoire selected in collaboration with their allocated teacher, that demonstrate a level of artistic and technical competency appropriate to their year level.

Composition students will prepare a portfolio of works in consultation with their tutor equivalent to 10 minutes, to be submitted via Blackboard in the form of both scores and recordings.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Recitals will be scheduled to take place in the Nickson Room during the examination period. Piano accompaniment will be provided for applicable instruments. Details will be advised on Blackboard.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: You will receive a mark of 0 if this assessment is submitted late.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

learning_activities.topic:
Performance Workshop

Students in all Performance Studies courses are expected to attend the weekly workshop for their instrument group:

Brass

Composition

Piano

Lower Strings

Upper Strings

Percussion

Reeds

Voice

Flutes

Learning outcomes: L01, L02
learning_activities.topic_description: Performance Workshop Students in all Performance Studies courses are expected to attend the weekly workshop for their instrument group: Brass Composition Piano Lower Strings Upper Strings Percussion Reeds Voice Flutes

learning_activities.topic:
Practical Lessons

Students receive 12 one-hour lessons with an allocated teacher throughout the semester. Lessons are usually scheduled weekly during semester. Allocated teachers may agree to a different schedule if requested. The allocated teacher will advise if it is possible to reschedule lessons. Lessons are usually rescheduled only because of unforeseen circumstances, such as sudden illness.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02
learning_activities.topic_description: Practical Lessons Students receive 12 one-hour lessons with an allocated teacher throughout the semester. Lessons are usually scheduled weekly during semester. Allocated teachers may agree to a different schedule if requested. The allocated teacher will advise if it is possible to reschedule lessons. Lessons are usually rescheduled only because of unforeseen circumstances, such as sudden illness.

learning_activities.topic:
Ensemble and group music-making

All performance students are required to attend a weekly 2hr ensemble class in the period outlined relevant to their discipline. The information below offers a broad guide to activities and further information will be made available on Blackboard:


Brass

Flutes

Percussion

Reeds

Saxophone

Strings

Composition The contemporary ensemble class focuses on new compositions, contributed by members as well as drawn from international twenty-first century repertoire. Composition students in all Performance Studies courses are expected to attend the weekly classes, and to both play in and compose for the ensemble. The ensemble is open to any instrument or voice type, and students who are not studying composition are encouraged to participate and to compose new works for the ensemble. Within the Sketch Ensemble, there will be a separate Sketch Production Ensemble for approved students.

Lyric Diction for Voice Students Voice students in Performance Studies courses 1-3 are expected to attend the weekly class on language and diction. The aim of the workshops is to develop proficiency and competence in the major operatic languages (Italian in course 1, German in course 2, French in course 3) so that students can perform in these languages with a high degree of accuracy and confidence. Students are taught the phonetic representation and correct physiological formation of sounds of each of these languages, and practice songs in these languages.

Piano Collaborative Class Piano students in all Performance Studies courses are expected to attend the weekly piano collaborative class. Piano students are assigned duo or trio work with an instrumentalist or vocalist, and work with their nominated collaborative artist(s). Piano students may be expected to attend one-on-one lessons for their collaborative partner(s) and to have their collaborative partner(s) attend their one-on-one lessons.


Students are welcome to attend as many classes relevant to their skills as they wish. However they will only be assessed on one activity. All students are strongly encouraged to attend and participate in the Contemporary Music Ensemble and Piano Collaborative Class even if they are being assessed in other groups. All students must attend and participate in any performances linked to these learning activities including Project Week.

Learning outcomes: L02, L03

All students must attend and participate in any performances linked to these learning activities including Project Week.

learning_activities.topic:
Nickson Room Concerts

Students in all Performance Studies courses are encouraged to attend the public concerts in the Nickson Room every Thursday during semester. Please see Blackboard for further details.


Learning outcomes: L02, L03
learning_activities.topic_description: Nickson Room Concerts Students in all Performance Studies courses are encouraged to attend the public concerts in the Nickson Room every Thursday during semester. Please see Blackboard for further details.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Exam week 2
learning_activities.topic:
Private Practice

Students are expected to practice intensively throughout the semester, including non-teaching weeks. Please ask your teachers for advice about the appropriate frequency and length of practice time for your instrument, voice or composition studies.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02
learning_activities.topic_description: Private Practice Students are expected to practice intensively throughout the semester, including non-teaching weeks. Please ask your teachers for advice about the appropriate frequency and length of practice time for your instrument, voice or composition studies.

learning_activities.topic:
Project Week

The School of Music suspends all regular classes for one week each semester and schedules a week of special events, ensemble rehearsals, seminars and workshops, culminating in various performances at a number of internal and external venues which will be advised on Blackboard. Students are expected to attend all relevant seminars, presentations, rehearsals and performances to their area of study.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03

Students are expected to attend all relevant seminars, presentations, rehearsals and performances to their area of study.
